comment_data.body:
Hmm, I thought that this was documented, but at least I can't find it right now.

This is intentional. When you use Python type annotations, it would be weird if you lost Python exception propagation semantics along the way, just by compiling the code. So the default behaviour is "except? -1" here for C integer types.

https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/25d042da09bfee6e67b8b042c867623d8cf9a69d/Cython/Compiler/Nodes.py#L701-L710

Arguably, this would also be a better default for the decorator case. Probably worth discussing if Cython 3.0 is a good time to change it there as well.
See a3ffd72f344b543a57dbc213e1952ee20567d54d, looks like this has been around since 0.27.

> This is intentional. When you use Python type annotations, it would be weird if you lost Python exception propagation semantics along the way, just by compiling the code.

Even if those type annotations use cython types (as in the OP)? Could those annotated types not be inspected whether they actually need python?

> Could those annotated types not be inspected whether they actually need python?

I read your question as "could those annotated functions not be analysed to see if they actually raise exceptions", is that what you meant? Then the answer is: yes, not entirely easily, but they could. We currently only let that analysis fall out for free at code generation time, but do not have it available when we determine the function type. It would be an improvement in this case. But lacking that earlier analysis, I think safe exception raising is better than silently ignoring them.

Also note that the exception check is really cheap here, especially since `-1` is not even a normal return value in the example at hand. I'd be surprised if it cost more than one CPU cycle on average.

>>> @scoder: This is intentional. When you use **Python type annotations**, it would be weird if you lost Python exception propagation semantics along the way, just by compiling the code.

>> @h-vetinari: Even if those type annotations use cython types (as in the OP)? Could those annotated types not be inspected whether they actually need python?

> @scoder: I read your question as "could those annotated functions not be analysed to see if they actually raise exceptions", is that what you meant?

I was responding mainly to "python type annotations" (my bold), and how the OP used type annotations, but not python ones. But IIUC, you're saying that the (python) types are much less relevant here than the (python) exception behaviour.

I don't think analysing functions for whether they raise or not is reasonable. But maybe having a way (another decorator?) to indicate that the function *will not* raise (or shouldn't be checked for exceptions) would provide what's desired here?

@h-vetinari After experimenting with the output from ```cython -a```, I found that this is what ```@cython.exceptval(check=False)``` does. It turns the exception checking off. The documentation did not indicate this behavior though.

> The documentation did not indicate this behavior though.

PR welcome.
I updated the documentation and changed the behaviour of the decorator. I don't think there is more to do here.

milestone.description:
Goals:
 New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
 Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
 Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
 Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Cython in pure mode generates bogus interaction with Python when using PEP484/526 syntax instead of decorators
